content.raw:
I realize this is part of our current style guidelines, but it strikes me as an anti-pattern to have to qualify objects with their namespace when you're already in their namespace scope. It feels like pushing a problem down the road that will only get worse over time.

Obviously that's all part of a much larger discussion, and this PR is just trying to satisfy our current rule set, but I think this is a good example of where our style rules force us into using workarounds which should not be necessary.
content.html:
I realize this is part of our current style guidelines, but it strikes me as an anti-pattern to have to qualify objects with their namespace when you're already in their namespace scope. It feels like pushing a problem down the road that will only get worse over time.

Obviously that's all part of a much larger discussion, and this PR is just trying to satisfy our current rule set, but I think this is a good example of where our style rules force us into using workarounds which should not be necessary.

content.raw: It's especially confusing here because `log::Descriptor` is a class name whereas `Log::Descriptor` is a function name. Granted, part of the problem there is having a class with a similar name to a namespace, but the issue could be avoided entirely if we consistently used a clause instead of just a noun for function names, and reserved plain nouns for class names.
content.html: It's especially confusing here because log::Descriptor is a class name whereas Log::Descriptor is a function name. Granted, part of the problem there is having a class with a similar name to a namespace, but the issue could be avoided entirely if we consistently used a clause instead of just a noun for function names, and reserved plain nouns for class names.
